'''''Cortinarius australiensis''''', commonly known as the '''skirt webcap''', is a species of mushroom in the genus ''[[Cortinarius]]'' native to Australia and New Zealand. The white mushrooms appear in autumn and can grow very large, with their [[pileus (mycology)|caps]] reaching {{convert|30|cm|abbr=on}} in diameter.

==Taxonomy==
The mushrooms was originally [[species description|described]] by [[John Burton Cleland]] and [[Edwin Cheel]] in 1918 as ''Rozites australiensis''.<ref name="Cleland 1918"/> Cleland later (1924) placed it in ''Locellina'',<ref name="Cleland 1924"/> a now-defunct genus that has since been folded into ''[[Cortinarius]]''.<ref name="urlFungorum: Locellina"/> Egon Horak transferred the species to ''Cortinarius'' in 1981, giving it the [[Binomial nomenclature|binomial]] by which it is now known.<ref name="Horak 1981"/>

[[Taxonomy (biology)|Classified]] in ''Cortinarius'' [[subgenus]] ''Phlegmacium'', ''C. australiensis'' is the [[type species]] of [[series (botany)|series]] ''Australiensium'' as defined by Bruno Gasparini in 2006. This is a grouping of related Southern Hemisphere species characterized by an abundant [[universal veil]], medium to large and pale [[basidiocarp|fruitbodies]], and ellipsoid to amygdaliform (almond-shaped) [[basidiospore|spores]].<ref name="Gasparini 2007"/> It is commonly known as the skirt webcap.<ref name="fungimap"/>

==Description==
[[File:Cortinarius australiensisLNCP1.jpg|thumb|left|Immature mushroom covered in cortina]]
The fruitbodies of this fungus have convex to flattened [[pileus (mycology)|caps]] with diameters typically in the range {{convert|5|to|7.5|cm|abbr=on}},<ref name="Grgurinovic 1997"/> although specimens up to {{convert|30|cm|abbr=on}} have been noted.<ref name="Bougher 1998"/> There is no discernible odour.<ref name="Cleland 1918"/> The cap colour is whitish with brown tints, and ragged fragments of the [[partial veil]] often remain attached to the cap margin. The stipe is bulbous, with dimensions of {{convert|15|cm|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|3.7|–|6.2|cm|abbr=on}}, although it is often much smaller than this. The [[lamella (mycology)|gills]] on the cap underside have an initially [[adnation|adnate]] attachment to the stipe and pale straw colour; later, the gill attachment becomes sinuate to nearly free, and colour deepens to rusty brown as the spores mature.<ref name="Grgurinovic 1997"/> The gills can be up to {{convert|1|cm|abbr=on|1}} deep.<ref name="Bougher 1998"/> Remnants of a [[annulus (mycology)|ring]] often persist on the stipe until maturity, as well as bits of the universal veil that once enclosed the immature mushroom.<ref name="Grgurinovic 1997"/> The ring is often stained dark brown from the spores falling from the gills.<ref name="Bougher 1998"/> The ellipsoid to almond-shaped [[basidiospore|spores]] measure 10–13 by 5.4–6.9 [[micrometre|µm]],<ref name="Grgurinovic 1997"/> and turn yellowish brown in [[potassium hydroxide|KOH]]. Western Australian specimens have slightly larger spores, averaging 11.1 by 5.9 µm.<ref name="Bougher 1998"/>

The [[edible mushroom|edibility]] of this mushroom is unknown, and it should be avoided, as some of its close relatives contain lethal toxins. Young fruitbodies of ''C. australiensis'' can resemble those of ''[[Amanita ovoidea]]''.<ref name="Gasparini 2007"/> ''C. australiensis'' can be mistaken for the similar-looking dumpy webcap (''[[Cortinarius sublargus]]''), though the latter species is generally smaller, lacks the prominent ring and generally only grows in recently burnt areas.<ref name="fungimap"/>

==Habitat and distribution==
''Cortinarius australiensis'' has been recorded from [[New South Wales]], and [[Mount Lofty Ranges]], [[Kuitpo Forest|Kuitpo]] and [[Ashton, South Australia|Ashton]] in South Australia.<ref name="Cleland 1976"/> It has been recorded from the wet forests of [[Tasmania]], but is rare there.<ref name="Ratkowsky 2005"/> The fungus is [[mycorrhiza]]l with [[eucalypt]]s.<ref name="Keane 2000"/> Large clumps of fruitbodies appear in eucalypt forests between April and July.<ref name="Fuhrer 2005"/> ''C. australiensis'' has the largest mushrooms of any species native to [[Jarrah forest]]s of southwestern Australia, and they are often eaten by native mammals.<ref name="Dell 2012"/> The mushroom also occurs in New Zealand, where it grows with ''[[Leptospermum]]''.<ref name="Grgurinovic 1997"/>
